content.location: Second route from the left on the wall at the top of the approach trail.
First route on the right on the wall at the top of the approach trail.

content.description: Long moves to small pockets on steep stone. Changes to vert at the top.
content.protection: 4 bolts to anchors at the top with leaver biners.
content.location: From the top of the approach trail go left and walk along the wall for approximately 50 yards until you come upon a wall with three routes. There is a large flake resting against a tree in front of this wall. This is the middle route.

content.description: Tough start through some choss, then the angle increases as the stone turns bullet.
content.location: From the top of the approach trail go left and walk along the wall for approximately 50 yards until you come upon a wall with three routes. There is a large flake resting against a tree in front of this wall. This is the rightmost of the three routes.

content.description: Open Project. The first three bolts are shared with The Yin. Three more bolts on the face then anchors. Bring your night vision goggles cuz this bad boy is LIGHTS OUT!

climbs.name: Overzealous
climbs.fa: Unknown - Probably Raud as he was scoping out Jealous

content.description: Did you get psyched on the beautiful high quality Jealous line and roll up to the crag alone with one pad only to realize your not up for committing to the high ball bad landing fall that is sure to ensue?  Well your effort was not wasted.  A little tamer in difficulty and grade, this may be your next best bet.  Depending on whether you sit start or stand start the grade can feel anywhere from V0 to V2.  Climb up the top corner of the face on decent pockets or move all the way into the jug filled crack and top out in the same spot as Jealous.
Pulls the wave-like bulge. Stays tough at the top.
Climb the slab past two bolts to a ledge. A hard crux right off the ledge leads to easier climbing.
content.location: From the top of the approach trail turn left and walk to twenty yards to the next section of wall. There are two routes here; this is the righthand route.

content.description: Start on slab and go to a ledge/rest. Continue your way up into a small dihedral at the very top to clip the chains.
content.protection: 6 Bolts. Should have perma draws at anchors unless they've been taken.
content.location: The beginning of the route starts on a broken flake that's leaning against the wall.

content.description: Start at the bottom left of the boulder on some underclings and move toward the prow for the finish. Sustained moves from bottom to top. Looks very hard from a distance. Look closely and you'll find everything you need is right there. I'm surprised a line/face like this exists in Iowa.
content.location: Right off the trail near the 187 Wall. You can't miss it. Down climb the easy crack on the left of the boulder.

content.description: Sustained movement throughout the entire problem. Classic roof climbing movement. Reminds me  bit of some bouldering down in Cowell, Arkansas
content.location: 50 feet to the right of "Jealous" near the 187 wall. Take a left on a trail that leads up to a cave. The route starts on the right of the cave on an obvious big jug.
From the top of the approach trail turn left and walk to twenty yards to the next section of wall. There are two routes here; this is the lefthand route.

climbs.name: Aggregating Anenome
climbs.fa: M. Black, equipped by Alan Grau

content.description: Climb up easy slab to better rock where the wall starts to slightly overhang then move left along the bolt line to pull a fun bouldery bulge sequence .  After the bulge, clip one more bolt to the anchors up left. Use an extended draw down low to avoid rope drag.  Everything on this route is OK for the capable 10d climber but pulling the bulge feels stout.  Thank you to Alan G. and other developers for bolting this line and the others surrounding.

187 Crag is located just past Hoot Bluff along 187th St. It is on the west facing section of the bluffline and stays well-shaded throughout the summer months. It features a handful of lines in the 5.11-12 range.
